comments.body:
Do we want to keep using Version 1 of the API?

```
The v1.0 endpoints are the older version of the LibAnswers API but are still supported for backward compatibility. If you are currently using the v1.0 endpoints, you do not need to change your existing calls. However, we encourage you to use the v1.1 endpoints.
```

The comments lead to me to believe that shutdown of the current version(1.0) is not currently scheduled for shutdown. If it's a very modest change (at a glance it seems the main difference would be adding authentication) it's probably worth switching to the later version.

orangelight.title: Seek Feedback from Catalog Stakeholders on "new" Advanced Search Form

comments.body:
Message for stakeholders

****
The DACS team is excited to invite you to test a new release of the catalog running Blacklight 8 in our catalog-qa environment. This release of Blacklight is focused on improving application preformance and implementing compatibility with newer versions of the Solr indexing server we use to index our catalog data. The release strives to implement the same search functionality the current catalog has for our basic and advanced search features. 

The new release will be available for the new two weeks in the QA environment. To test you need to do the following.

1. Connect to Global Protect if you are off campus or on on campus wifi. 
2. Visit https://catalog-qa.princeton.edu.
3. Utilize the system, particularly the search features both basic and advanced. 
4. Please report errors or questions to this email thread or in slack on either the catalog or orangelight channels. 
5. When reporting an error please try and capture the URL and a screenshot (if possible) where you encountered something unexpected. Try and describe the issue in as much detail as you can. 

Thanks for assisting with evaluating this release,

Regards,
DACS Team

I am nearly complete with extending the `Work` model to support embargo dates, however, my only delay has been some ongoing troubleshooting with Sass preprocessing for improving the styling for the form:

![image](https://github.com/pulibrary/pdc_describe/assets/1443986/ef0dfea6-90a6-4b58-a203-9fdb67581517)

comments.body:
I can re-create this error in staging by naming a file with the same naming scheme used by the erroring object: `Dry He 2mm 15kV le=0.8mJ RH 50%.csv`

When I intentionally raise the error encountered by AWS, instead of just logging it, I get:

> An error was encountered when requesting to copy AWS S3 Object from /pdc-describe-staging-precuration/10.80021/k5jr-ay36/467/Dry He 2mm 15kV le=0.8mJ RH 50%.csv to 10.80021/k5jr-ay36/467/Dry He 2mm 15kV le=0.8mJ RH 50%.csv in the bucket pdc-describe-staging-postcuration: Invalid copy source encoding
Looks like maybe we need to url encode the filename? https://stackoverflow.com/questions/76935265/aws-s3-copy-object-fails-when-object-name-contains-with-an-error-invalid-co

comments.body: One question, how would we propagate the change for datasets that are either published or under review for this collection?

@astrochun When we run the rake task (documented here: https://github.com/pulibrary/pdc_describe/blob/70da0f069b120110f3ccfaccf39837c6b538ac11/docs/bulk_metadata_updates.md) that will update all of the records in the system, regardless of whether they are in review or have already been published.

Great!

princeton_ansible.title: Use a template for our simplest nginx configs

comments.body:
A quick look at a few config files uncovers a few differences among sites. Known needed changes:
- [ ] add a var for the HTTP [load-balancing technique](https://www.nginx.com/blog/choosing-nginx-plus-load-balancing-techniques/) (see annotations-prod)
- [ ] add a section for enabling/disabling `app_protect` (see abid-staging)
- [ ] allow more than one included `restrict` file (see bibdata-qa)
- [ ] regularize an `ansible-managed` comment

With these changes done, we can try using the template for these sites:
- [ ] abid
- [ ] annotations
- [ ] ansible-tower
- [ ] approvals
- [ ] bibdata
- [ ] byzantine-tsp
- [ ] cicognara
- [ ] eal-apps
. . . and probably more.

Once the changes are ready, we can put the vars in place and create the templated files in `/tmp/`, then diff the files against the actual nginxplus config files to identify any changes/drift.
Add a variable for the health check page (see Drupal sites for examples).
I have run this successfully on `lib-postgres-prod1`
